results.title: Meet the People
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Blurring the line between documentary and fiction, truth and artifice, Meet the People presents fourteen ‘characters’ who face the camera in talking head close-ups and speak about their lives and dreams. The intimacy and honesty of their fragmented, autobiographical storytelling is illusory; the credits reveal that these people are professional actors, playing fictional roles, reading a script. As Silver writes, this work points to a complicity on the part of the viewer in his desire to believe and identify with the traditions of and characters on TV. The same television that mimics a perfected form of the identity of the ‘average person’ is also in part responsible for creating this identity; it both researches, uses and manufactures this ‘average person’s‘ hopes and dreams. And so the question of a ‘real person’ becomes ‘real’ compared to what?

results.title: Agnes, Maude & Pearly too
results.creator_credit: Erica Glynn, Alice Jacques, Charles Mitchell and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Two sisters meet up to play pokies on their deceased sister’s favourite pokie machine before scattering her ashes. Shortly afterward, their grief compounds and the truth of the past is revealed and confronted.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Erica Glynn, Alice Jacques, Charles Mitchell and AFTRS

results.title: Agnes, Maude and Pearly too
results.creator_credit: Kate Gillick, Charles Mitchell, Aline Jacques, Erica Glynn and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
On this day, in loving memory of Pearly, Agnes and Maude play a game on Pearly’s favourite poker machine. But when they hit the jackpot, money isn’t the only thing that comes spilling out.
Cast: Julie Godfrey (Agnes), Jacquy Phillips (Maude)

results.title: Redreaming the dark
results.creator_credit: Romaine Moreton, Charlotte Seymour, Erica Glynn and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
During an electricity blackout in the family apartment, a young intellectually challenged Black woman has her life suddenly thrown into turmoil. Her grandmother soothes the young girl, teaching her not only to embrace the dark but also to love her dark self. Together the three women “redream” the dark.
Cast: Emily Walker, Leah Purcell, Irma Woods

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The “Bush Mechanics” comprise of a group of five young Warlpiri Aboriginal men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their clever inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, this series follows the “Bush Mechanics” across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits, including the race to Willowra to play their first paying gig as a rock band, the travel to Alice Springs to collect Simeon’s nephew from jail, the chase for their stolen car and finally covering thousands of kilometers across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Gulpilil: one red blood
results.creator_credit: David Gulpilil, Darlene Johnson, Tom Zubrycki and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: David Gulpilil is one of the most respected Australian actors of his generation. Born in 1953, he grew up on an Aboriginal reserve and worked as a stockman. Possessing exceptional talents as a dancer, at age 14 he was chosen to play the lead in Nicholas Roeg’s film ‘Walkabout’ (1970). He went on to act in a number of Australian feature films including ‘Mad Dog Morgan’ (1976), ‘Storm Boy’ (1977), ‘The Last Wave’ (1977), ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (1986) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Most recently he won the AFI award for best actor for his performance in ‘The Tracker’ (2002). When he is not acting, Gulpilil lives a demanding traditional life in Arnhem Land, Northern Australia where he is an elder of the Yolngu clan. Following Gulpilil from the set of ‘The Tracker’ back to his community the film reveals how the actor negotiates the two very different worlds he moves between. Interviews with Phillip Noyce, Rolf De Heer, Marcia Langton, Gary Foley, Jack Thompson, and others, as well as with Gulpilil, are interspersed with clips from films in which the actor has appeared.

results.title: Two bob mermaid
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, Antonia Barnard and Core Films
results.brief_description: In this visually stunning short film set in the 1950s, a fair-skinned Aboriginal girl gains access to the local swimming pool where Aboriginal people are legally denied access (Source: Australian Screen)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darlene Johnson, Antonia Barnard and Core Films
results.description: In this visually stunning short film set in the 1950s, a fair-skinned Aboriginal girl gains access to the local swimming pool where Aboriginal people are legally denied access (Source: Australian Screen)

results.title: You dust mite be next
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, Chris Aronsten, Kate Reidl, Jane Keneally and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A docudrama about the evil little dust mite that plagues the world using up close and personal microscopic images, horror tales from victims and a biology lesson from experts Dr Ewan Tovey and Michael Morris.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darlene Johnson, Chris Aronsten, Kate Reidl, Jane Keneally and AFTRS
